   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days leading to this
   rapid decline.  Currently intubated, stable on ventilator
   - Continue ventilation, wean as tolerated
   - f/u sputum culture final results, currently yeast
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean from ventilator today given continued fluid overload
   and hypotension requiring pressors, will reassess once HD able to take
   off fluid
   - will obtain blood cultures today for surveillance, consider
   antifungal if blood cultures indicate yeast as is seen in current
   sputum cultures.
   - Cont daily trial of pressure support at 15/10.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Is on midodrine at HD for hypotension
   as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal decrease in
   required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses prn, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - HD today, will plan for likely zero UF.
   - continue check central venous sat, yesterday [**3-2**] was 70, to help
   determine if hypovolemia/cardiogenic vs. sepsis as cause of hypotension
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen much more tender
   this morning, no recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess
   for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perf.  Will hold off for now
   currently, will plan CT as clinical status changes
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Avoid excessive narcotics
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - d/c lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - F/u Surgery and GI recs
 their input appreciated
   - d/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 91**] regarding possible options
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder scan to assess UOP status in setting of unclear
   interpretation of elevated bladder pressures
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   - seriel abd pressures, last bladder pressure 22 and 24, unable to
   interpret given body habitus, fluid overload.
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for CVVH today once new IR guided HD line placed
   - d/c midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay
   - Heme recs possible HIV test, consider vanco as additional source of
   [**Month (only) 453**] plts.
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue HD for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; currently on fent/versed due to
   increase in abd tenderness
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today [**3-3**] is day 12 of antibiotics. Per report, appears to be
   improving.  Not producing BM
   - Continue PO vanc/flagyl to complete at least a 14 day course
   - cont PR vanco given possibility PO vanco is not getting through
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed.  Will place insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, will add insulin to TPN
   - Meds via OGT
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR,
   lansoprazole
   .
   # Access: R CVL placed [**2-20**].  Plan for pt to go to IR today for change
   of R CVL with L HD CVL for continued HD.
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, Son [**Name (NI) 5420**] who requests that no specific
   information be given to other family members
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now
   ICU Care

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male with a complex medical history, including acute renal failure, chronic liver disease, hepatitis B and C, and Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) colitis. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation for hypoxic respiratory failure, which is likely secondary to aspiration.

The patient's laboratory results indicate:

* WBC: 21.1
* Hct: 28.0
* Plt: 112
* Cr: 6.9
* TCO2: 22
* Glucose: 80
* Lactic Acid: 2.4 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.9 g/dL
* LDH: 261 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.7 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.6 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure
* Acute renal failure
* C. diff colitis
* Hepatitis B and C
* Chronic liver disease
* Thrombocytopenia (questionable HIT)
* Oliguric acute renal failure
* Coagulopathy
* Delirium
* Hematochezia (resolved)
* Air near the tail of the pancreas (questionable microperforation vs pancreatico-colonic fistula)
* Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Sepsis
* Multi-organ dysfunction
* Respiratory failure
* Renal failure
* Hepatic encephalopathy
* Coagulopathy
* Bleeding
* Infection
* Pancreatitis
* Bowel obstruction
* Small bowel obstruction
* Intestinal perforation
* Abscess
* Fistula

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue ventilation and wean as tolerated
* Treat for HAP/aspiration with vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole
* Continue to follow daily CXR for possible aspiration event
* Obtain blood cultures for surveillance and consider antifungal therapy if yeast is detected
* Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
* Fluid boluses prn, but avoid given renal failure
* Plan for CVVH today once new IR-guided HD line is placed
* Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology
* Consider repeat CT abdomen/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perfusion

The patient's family has been informed of his condition and has requested that no specific information be given to other family members. The patient's code status is full code.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, sepsis, and multi-organ dysfunction. He has been receiving continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to acute kidney injury. His blood pressure has been dropping, requiring titration of his levothyroxine (Levo) medication. He has also been experiencing abdominal pain, tenderness, and distension, with a history of ascites and Clostridium difficile infection. His laboratory results show thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and acute kidney injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction increase his risk of developing sepsis-related complications, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury, and cardiac dysfunction.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's ongoing AKI and need for CVVH increase his risk of developing chronic kidney disease and the need for long-term dialysis.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation increase his risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and respiratory muscle weakness.
4. Hepatitis: The patient's history of hepatitis and elevated liver enzymes increase his risk of developing further liver damage and liver failure.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and ascites increase his risk of developing further bleeding and gastrointestinal complications.
6. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension increase his risk of developing cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac failure.
7. Infection: The patient's history of sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction increase his risk of developing further infections, such as pneumonia and urinary tract infections.
8. Malnutrition: The patient's need for total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and his history of diabetes mellitus increase his risk of developing malnutrition and its associated complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated, stable on
   ventilator
   - Continue ventilation, wean as tolerated on pressure support
   - f/u cultures
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean sedation today given need for patient to be still
   for CVVH
   - will attempt to slowly diurese with CVVH to remove fluid, however BP
   may not tolerate.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal
   decrease in required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses if needed, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - cont CVVH today, will plan for some net removal of fluid.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with increased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male with a complex medical history, including acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, cirrhosis, hepatitis B and C, and Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) colitis. The patient has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for management of his acute respiratory failure and has undergone several interventions, including intubation, mechanical ventilation, and continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated with a tidal volume of 540 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 12 cmH2O. The patient's oxygenation status is satisfactory, with an arterial oxygen saturation (SaO2) of 100%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient is receiving norepinephrine to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg. The patient's cardiac rhythm is sinus rhythm, and his blood pressure is 114/65 mmHg.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury and is receiving CVVH. His serum creatinine level is 4.0 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 23 mg/dL.
* Hepatic: The patient has cirrhosis and is at risk for bleeding and ascites. His liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with a total bilirubin level of 2.2 mg/dL and an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 97 IU/L.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has C. diff colitis and is receiving treatment with vancomycin and metronidazole. He has not had a bowel movement for 14 days and is at risk for bowel obstruction.
* Hematological: The patient has thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 109,000/mL. He has a positive HIT antibody and is at risk for bleeding.
* Neurological: The patient has delirium and is receiving treatment with midazolam and fentanyl.

Potential medical complications that may arise in this patient include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is fragile, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
* Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to his underlying medical conditions and the presence of C. diff colitis.
* Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and cirrhosis make him at risk for bleeding.
* Bowel obstruction: The patient's C. diff colitis and ileus make him at risk for bowel obstruction.
* Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's cirrhosis and elevated ammonia levels make him at risk for hepatic encephalopathy.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury and underlying chronic kidney disease make him at risk for further renal deterioration.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension and requirement for vasopressors make him at risk for cardiovascular instability.

In conclusion, this patient has a complex medical condition with multiple potential complications. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's condition remains critical. The patient has been experiencing hypotension, with a blood pressure dropping to 70s mmHg, requiring titration of vasopressors and increased fluid resuscitation. The patient's cardiac rhythm is normal, with a heart rate of 90 bpm. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 100% on CPAP/PSV ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 109 K/uL, and elevated liver enzymes, including ALT and AST. The patient's renal function is compromised, with a creatinine level of 4.0 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 24 mg/dL. The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperphosphatemia.

The patient's medical history includes type II diabetes, hypertension, and a history of gastrointestinal bleed, which may contribute to the patient's current condition. The patient has also been diagnosed with acute kidney injury, respiratory failure, and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Hemodynamic instability, potentially leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure, potentially requiring invasive mechanical ventilation.
3. Renal failure, potentially requiring dialysis.
4. Thrombotic complications, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, due to the patient's HIT.
5. Infection, potentially leading to sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding, potentially leading to hypovolemic shock.
7. Hypocalcemia, potentially leading to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle cramps.
8. Hyperglycemia, potentially leading to diabetic ketoacidosis.

Given the patient's critical condition, close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated, stable on
   ventilator
   - Continue ventilation, wean as tolerated, trial of pressure support
   - f/u culture final results
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean from ventilator today given continued fluid overload
   and hypotension requiring pressors, will reassess once CVVH able to
   take off fluid
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal
   decrease in required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses if needed, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - cont CVVH today, will plan for likely zero UF.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with increased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess
   for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perf.  Will hold off for now
   currently, will plan CT as clinical status changes
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Avoid excessive narcotics
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - F/u Surgery and GI recs
 their input appreciated
   - d/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 91**] regarding possible options
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder scan yesterday showed 18, cont to monitor
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today
   - holding on midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay
   - Heme recs possible HIV test, consider vanco as additional source of
   [**Month (only) 453**] plts.
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; currently on fent/versed due to
   increase in abd tenderness
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today ([**3-4**]) is day 13 of antibiotics. Per report, appears to
   be improving.  Not producing BM
   - Continue PO vanc/flagyl to complete at least a 14 day course
   - cont PR vanco given possibility PO vanco is not getting through
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed.  Will increase insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, insulin in TPN
   - Meds via OGT
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR,
   lansoprazole
   .
   # Access: L CVL placed [**3-4**] (originally R-sided placed on [**2-20**]).  R HD
   for CVVH
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, Son [**Name (NI) 5420**] who requests that no specific
   information be given to other family members
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now

   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean from ventilator today given continued fluid overload
   and hypotension requiring pressors, will reassess once CVVH able to
   take off fluid
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal
   decrease in required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses if needed, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - cont CVVH today, will plan for likely zero UF.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with increased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess
   for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perf.  Will hold off for now
   currently, will plan CT as clinical status changes
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Avoid excessive narcotics
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - F/u Surgery and GI recs
 their input appreciated
   - d/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 91**] regarding possible options
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder scan yesterday showed 18, cont to monitor
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today
   - holding on midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay
   - Heme recs possible HIV test, consider vanco as additional source of
   [**Month (only) 453**] plts.
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; currently on fent/versed due to
   increase in abd tenderness
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today ([**3-4**]) is day 13 of antibiotics. Per report, appears to
   be improving.  Not producing BM
   - Continue PO vanc/flagyl to complete at least a 14 day course
   - cont PR vanco given possibility PO vanco is not getting through
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed.  Will increase insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, insulin in TPN
   - Meds via OGT
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR,
   lansoprazole
   .
   # Access: L CVL placed [**3-4**] (originally R-sided placed on [**2-20**]).  R HD
   for CVVH
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, Son [**Name (NI) 5420**] who requests that no specific
   information be given to other family members
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and sepsis. He has a history of chronic liver disease, hepatitis B and C, and is currently being treated for Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) colitis and peritonitis. He has developed hypotension, requiring vasopressors, and is on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) for acute kidney injury. He also has a history of thrombocytopenia, which may be related to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely related to sepsis, acute kidney injury, and possible vasopressor-resistant shock. Further evaluation with echocardiogram and vasopressin may be necessary to determine the underlying cause.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely related to sepsis, acute tubular necrosis, and possible prerenal azotemia. CVVH is being used to support renal function, and further evaluation with nephrology consultation is necessary to determine the underlying cause and plan for further management.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely related to C. diff colitis, peritonitis, and possible aspiration. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are being used to cover all potential pathogens, and further evaluation with serial blood cultures and imaging studies is necessary to determine the underlying cause and plan for further management.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be related to HIT, and further evaluation with serotonin assay and platelet function studies is necessary to determine the underlying cause. Avoidance of heparin products and possible treatment with argatroban may be necessary.
5. C. diff Colitis: The patient's C. diff colitis is being treated with vancomycin and metronidazole, and further evaluation with serial stool cultures and abdominal exams is necessary to determine the response to treatment.
6. Peritonitis: The patient's peritonitis is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, and further evaluation with serial abdominal exams and imaging studies is necessary to determine the response to treatment.
7. Air near Tail of Pancreas: The patient's air near the tail of the pancreas may be related to microperforation or pancreaticocolonic fistula. Further evaluation with imaging studies and surgical consultation is necessary to determine the underlying cause and plan for further management.
8. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is likely related to liver disease and nutritional deficiency. Further evaluation with coagulation studies and vitamin K administration is necessary to determine the underlying cause and plan for further management.
9. Delirium: The patient's delirium is likely related to uremia, hepatic encephalopathy, and severe infection. Further evaluation with serial mental status exams and treatment with CVVH and broad-spectrum antibiotics is necessary to determine the underlying cause and plan for further management.

The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of abdominal pain, thrombocytopenia, and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). The patient has a complex medical history, including type II diabetes, hypertension, and a history of gastrointestinal bleed, lower. The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy in place. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.1F, heart rate of 103 bpm, and blood pressure of 88/53 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support is set to CPAP/PSV with a FiO2 of 40%. The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 18.8, hemoglobin of 9.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 109.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and the risk of respiratory failure is high. The patient's PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 258, which is within the normal range, but the patient's respiratory rate is 21, which is above the normal range.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleed and lower gastrointestinal bleed, which increases the risk of sepsis. The patient's white blood cell count is 18.8, which is above the normal range.
3. Renal failure: The patient has a history of acute renal failure, and the patient's creatinine level is 2.2 mg/dL, which is above the normal range. The patient's urine output is 15 mL, which is below the normal range.
4. Hepatic failure: The patient has a history of hepatitis, and the patient's liver function tests show elevated levels of liver enzymes.
5. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleed and lower gastrointestinal bleed, which increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of hypertension and hypotension, which increases the risk of cardiovascular complications.
7. Nutritional complications: The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN), which increases the risk of nutritional complications such as hyperglycemia and electrolyte imbalances.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, the patient is at high risk for developing these medical complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a complex medical history, including type II diabetes, hypertension, and a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, hepatitis, and renal failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, FiO2 40%, and PEEP 12 cmH2O. The patient's SpO2 is 100%, and the ABG results show a pH of 7.37, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 258, and a VE of 11.6 L/min.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has tachycardia, with a heart rate of 103 bpm, and normal S1 and S2 sounds. There are no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's CVP is 12 mmHg, and the total fluid input is 11,875 mL, with a balance of -475 mL.
* Renal: The patient is receiving continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH), and the renal prognosis is predicted to be poor.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has abdominal distension and tenderness, with distant bowel sounds. The patient has a history of ascites, C. difficile infection, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hematology: The patient has thrombocytopenia (platelet count 109 K/uL) and a prolonged PT/PTT/INR.
* Biochemistry: The patient has elevated liver enzymes (ALT 18 IU/L, AST 110 IU/L), alkaline phosphatase 230 IU/L, and lactate dehydrogenase 327 IU/L.
* Electrolytes: The patient has hypokalemia (K+ 2.2 mmol/L), hypomagnesemia (Mg++ 1.8 mmol/L), and hypophosphatemia (PO4 2.9 mmol/L).

The patient's medical complications and potential complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is high.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension (BP 88/53 mmHg) suggest cardiovascular instability.
* Renal failure: The patient's predicted poor renal prognosis and ongoing CVVH treatment increase the risk of acute kidney injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD).
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and abdominal distension and tenderness suggest a high risk of further bleeding.
* Infection: The patient's history of C. difficile infection and prolonged hospitalization increase the risk of nosocomial infections, including VAP and sepsis.
* Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and ongoing anticoagulation therapy increase the risk of bleeding complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing CVVH therapy
* Monitoring of respiratory status and adjusting ventilator settings as necessary
* Managing cardiovascular instability with vasopressors and fluids
* Monitoring and managing gastrointestinal bleeding and distension
* Maintaining tight glycemic control
* Continuously monitoring for and treating infections
* Monitoring for and managing bleeding complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated.  Appears acutely
   worse this AM in regards to his increasing pressor requirement as well
   as his worsening ABG on PS.
   - Given worsening overall hemodynamic status, will turn patient back
   onto rate.  No vent wean for now.
   - f/u cultures, [**2-29**] sputum with yeast
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean sedation today given need for patient to be still
   for CVVH
   - will attempt to slowly diurese with CVVH to remove fluid, however BP
   may not tolerate.
   - will discuss with ID regarding recommendations for possible addition
   of antifungal given previous sputum culture with yeast and development
   of worsening hemodynamics.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with steady
   increase in pressor requirement to attain required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - will add vasopressin at this point for second pressor
   - remains on CVVH
   - cont CVVH today, anticipate net even due to worsening hemodynamics.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with decreased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM, has not stooled in
   days.  Bladder pressure today 40.
   - will contact surgery regarding overall worsening status for
   recommendations regarding possibility of CT abd/pelvis and whether
   findings on CT a/p would change overall surgical plan.
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - will d/c PR vanco
   - F/u Surgery recs
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder pressure increasing
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today
   - holding on midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay (pending)
   - Heme recs
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; however, currently on fent/versed
   due to increase in abd tenderness and need for patient to remain still
   for CVVH
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today ([**3-6**]) is day 15 of antibiotics. Still not producing
   BM
s.  Worsening abd exam today.
   - will d/c PR vanco today, cont PO vanco
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed. insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, insulin in TPN
   - Meds via IV
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR, PPI
   .
   # Access: L-CVL placed [**3-4**] (originally R-sided placed on [**2-20**]).  R-HD
   line for CVVH
   .
   # Code: DNR per recent discussion with HCP son [**Name (NI) 5420**] on [**3-5**]
   .
   # Communication: Patient, Son [**Name (NI) 5420**] who requests that no specific
   information be given to other family members
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated.  Appears acutely
   worse this AM in regards to his increasing pressor requirement as well
   as his worsening ABG on PS.
   - Given worsening overall hemodynamic status, will turn patient back
   onto rate.  No vent wean for now.
   - f/u cultures, [**2-29**] sputum with yeast
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean sedation today given need for patient to be still
   for CVVH
   - will attempt to slowly diurese with CVVH to remove fluid, however BP
   may not tolerate.
   - will discuss with ID regarding recommendations for possible addition
   of antifungal given previous sputum culture with yeast and development
   of worsening hemodynamics.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with steady
   increase in pressor requirement to attain required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - will add vasopressin at this point for second pressor
   - remains on CVVH
   - cont CVVH today, anticipate net even due to worsening hemodynamics.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with decreased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM, has not stooled in
   days.  Bladder pressure today 40.
   - will contact surgery regarding overall worsening status for
   recommendations regarding possibility of CT abd/pelvis and whether
   findings on CT a/p would change overall surgical plan.
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - will d/c PR vanco
   - F/u Surgery recs
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder pressure increasing
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today
   - holding on midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay (pending)
   - Heme recs
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; however, currently on fent/versed
   due to increase in abd tenderness and need for patient to remain still
   for CVVH
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today ([**3-6**]) is day 15 of antibiotics. Still not producing
   BM
s.  Worsening abd exam today.
   - will d/c PR vanco today, cont PO vanco
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed. insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, insulin in TPN
   - Meds via IV
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR, PPI
   .
   # Access: L-CVL placed [**3-4**] (originally R-sided placed on [**2-20**]).  R-HD
   line for CVVH
   .
   # Code: DNR per recent discussion with HCP son [**Name (NI) 5420**] on [**3-5**]
   .
   # Communication: Patient, Son [**Name (NI) 5420**] who requests that no specific
   information be given to other family members
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, sepsis, and multi-organ dysfunction. The patient has a complex medical history, including acute renal failure, chronic liver disease, and hepatitis B and C.

The patient's current condition is critical, with ongoing hypotension requiring vasopressors, increasing pressor requirement, and worsening hemodynamics. The patient is also experiencing oliguric acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and delirium.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with a requirement for mechanical ventilation and increasing oxygen requirements. The patient's abdominal exam is concerning for ileus or small bowel obstruction, and the patient has not had a bowel movement in days.

The patient's laboratory results are concerning, with elevated liver enzymes, acute kidney injury, and thrombocytopenia. The patient's coagulopathy is likely related to liver disease and nutritional deficiencies.

The patient's treatment plan includes continued mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and CVVH for renal support. The patient is also receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected sepsis and peritonitis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening respiratory failure: The patient's increasing oxygen requirements and worsening hemodynamics suggest that the patient's respiratory failure may continue to deteriorate.
2. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing sepsis and suspected peritonitis increase the risk of further organ dysfunction and death.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's oliguric acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, increasing the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, increasing the risk of bleeding complications.
6. Delirium: The patient's delirium may worsen, increasing the risk of falls and other complications.
7. Abdominal complications: The patient's ileus or small bowel obstruction may worsen, leading to further complications such as perforation or abscess formation.
8. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver disease may worsen, leading to further encephalopathy and increased risk of death.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple organ dysfunction and a high risk of further complications. Close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent further deterioration and improve the patient's outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities, including:

1. Acute kidney injury (AKI) with predicted poor renal prognosis, requiring continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).
2. Thrombocytopenia with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) positivity, necessitating discontinuation of heparin products.
3. Abdominal pain with distended abdomen, poor dentition, and distant bowel sounds, suggesting potential gastrointestinal issues.
4. Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation, with a high risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
5. Hypertension, hypotension, and suspected acute kidney injury, indicating multi-organ dysfunction.
6. History of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI), gastrointestinal bleed, and diabetes mellitus (DM), type II.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Sepsis and septic shock due to the presence of CDI and potential gastrointestinal bleeding.
2. Respiratory failure and ventilator-associated complications, such as VAP, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and barotrauma.
3. Acute kidney injury progression to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation, potentially leading to peritonitis and sepsis.
5. Thrombotic complications, including pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).
6. Metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia, due to diabetes mellitus and nutritional support.
7. Infections, including urinary tract infections (UTIs), pneumonia, and sepsis, which can exacerbate the patient's condition.

Given the patient's complex medical situation, close monitoring and aggressive management of these conditions are crucial to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated, stable on
   ventilator
   - Continue ventilation, wean as tolerated on pressure support
   - f/u cultures
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean sedation today given need for patient to be still
   for CVVH
   - will attempt to slowly diurese with CVVH to remove fluid, however BP
   may not tolerate.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal
   decrease in required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses if needed, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - cont CVVH today, will plan for some net removal of fluid.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with increased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess
   for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perf.  Will hold off for now
   currently, will plan CT as clinical status changes
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Avoid excessive narcotics
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - F/u Surgery and GI recs
   - d/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 91**] regarding possible options, including initiating feeds today
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder scan yesterday showed 20, cont to monitor
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today
   - holding on midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay (pending)
   - Heme recs possible HIV test, consider vanco as additional source of
   [**Month (only) 453**] plts.
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; however, currently on fent/versed
   due to increase in abd tenderness and need for patient to remain still
   for CVVH
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today ([**3-5**]) is day 14 of antibiotics. Still not producing
   BM
   - Continue PO vanc/flagyl (now has had a 14 day course)
   - cont PR vanco given possibility PO vanco is not getting through
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed. insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes
   - Continue TPN for now, insulin in TPN
   - Meds via IV
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots given hematochezia and elevated INR, PPI
   .
   # Access: L-CVL placed [**3-4**] (originally R-sided placed on [**2-20**]).  R-HD
   line for CVVH
   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male with a complex medical history, including acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, cirrhosis, hepatitis B and C, and Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) colitis. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation, and has undergone continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to acute kidney injury.

The patient's current condition is critical, with a Glasgow coma scale of 8/15 and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%, and his blood pressure is 88/53 mmHg, which is slightly hypotensive. The patient's heart rate is 103 beats per minute, and his central venous pressure (CVP) is 12 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 18.8 x 10^9/L, a platelet count of 109 x 10^9/L, and a creatinine level of 3.2 mg/dL. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) show elevated levels of aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT), and his bilirubin level is 2.2 mg/dL.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to aspiration, and he is being treated with mechanical ventilation and antibiotics.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's kidney injury is likely due to a combination of prerenal azotemia and acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and he is being treated with CVVH and dialysis.
3. C. diff colitis: The patient's C. diff colitis is being treated with antibiotics, and he has not produced a bowel movement in 14 days.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and he has a positive heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) antibody. He is being treated with anticoagulation therapy and is being monitored for bleeding complications.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's international normalized ratio (INR) is elevated, and he is being treated with vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma (FFP).
6. Delirium: The patient is experiencing delirium, which is likely due to a combination of uremia, hepatic encephalopathy, and severe infection.
7. Hematochezia: The patient's hematochezia has resolved, but he has received a total of 3 units of packed red blood cells.
8. Air near tail of pancreas: The patient has an air near the tail of his pancreas, which may be due to a microperforation or pancreatico-colonic fistula.

The patient's medical team is considering the following potential medical complications:

1. Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: The patient's abdominal symptoms may be due to afferent loop syndrome, ileus, or small bowel obstruction (SBO), and he is being treated with antibiotics and is being monitored for signs of obstruction.
2. Oliguric acute renal failure: The patient's kidney injury is likely due to a combination of prerenal azotemia and ATN, and he is being treated with CVVH and dialysis.
3. Thrombosis: The patient has a history of thrombosis, and he is at risk for developing further thrombosis due to his anticoagulation therapy.

The patient's family has been informed of his condition and has been advised to be present during his care. The patient's code status is full code.

   This is a 60 yo male with ARF, C diff, alc hep, Hep B and C, now with
   hypoxic respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure: Unclear what the precipitant was, but
   acute decompensation appears to be a result of aspiration.  Also, in
   the process of intubation, patient had copious emesis and continues to
   have significant OGT output.  Patient has had ileus versus obstruction
   that has been followed during his admission and he likely had
   significant residual gastric contents.  Patient is acutely ill and
   possibly had mini aspirations over the last 10 days prior to ICU
   leading to this rapid decline.  Currently intubated, stable on
   ventilator
   - Continue ventilation, wean as tolerated on pressure support
   - f/u cultures
   - Treat for HAP/aspiration with vanc/cefepime/flagyl as patient had
   been on vanc/ctx prior
   - Continue to follow daily CXR as patient likely experienced aspiration
   event and may develop infiltrate vs pneumonitis
   - Unlikely to wean sedation today given need for patient to be still
   for CVVH
   - will attempt to slowly diurese with CVVH to remove fluid, however BP
   may not tolerate.
   .
   # Hypotension: Became hypotensive in the setting of intubation and in
   spite of fluid boluses, continues to require levophed to maintain MAPs
   >65.  Has had asymptomatic hypotension on the floor multiple times
   responsive to fluid and albumin.  Has been on midodrine at HD for
   hypotension as well.  Currently remains on levophed with minimal
   decrease in required dose for MAP>65
   - Continue levophed to maintain MAP>65
   - Fluid boluses if needed, but would like to avoid given renal failure
   - cont CVVH today, will plan for some net removal of fluid.
   - Treat infection which includes peritonitis, c. diff and possible HAP
   - If continues with hypotension despite adequate treatment, would
   consider echo.
   - Consider vasopressin if needs second pressor.
   .
   # Afferent loop syndrome/ileus vs SBO: Has had questionable diagnosis
   per prior notes, has been followed by GI and surgery and was not felt
   to be a surgical candidate on multiple occasions.  Surgery feels
   percutaneous decompression not a good option.  If patient decompensates
   again, surgery may be considered as patient failing medical management,
   but with high likelihood of death also.  Surgery continues to follow
   and is amenable to surgical consideration if status changes with
   possible surgically correctable condition.  Abdomen with increased
   bowel sounds compared to yesterday. No recent BM.
   - Consider repeat CT abd/pelvis with IV/PO/rectal contrast to assess
   for obstruction/ileus/possible bowel perf.  Will hold off for now
   currently, will plan CT as clinical status changes
   - Continue to hold octreotide which may be worseing ileus
   - Avoid excessive narcotics
   - Continue to follow abdominal exam
   - holding lactulose
   - all IV meds as unclear if GI tract is working.
   - F/u Surgery and GI recs
   - d/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 91**] regarding possible options, including initiating feeds today
   - follow lactate, trending downward
   - Bladder scan yesterday showed 20, cont to monitor
   - Continue to readdress prognosis and status with family given option
   for medical management only
   .
   # Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Combination of ATN and prerenal
   azotemia.  Followed by nephrology and recently initiated HD per renal
   recommendations.  Also was treated temporarily for HRS, though given
   that octreotide can worsen SBO, treatment was discontinued.  On
   midodrine prior to HD for hypotension.  No hydro on US.
   - Continue to follow with nephrology and hepatology, appreciate their
   recommendations.
   - Plan for continued CVVH today
   - holding on midodrine
   - follow bladder pressure to rule out compartment syndrome
   - redose meds for CrCl of 20 given CVVH.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: question of patient having HIT given dropping
   platlets and positive HIT antibody. Heme consulted and feel that this
   may be false positive due to HD and we have sent serotonin assay.
   - f/u serotonin assay (pending)
   - Heme recs possible HIV test, consider vanco as additional source of
   [**Month (only) 453**] plts.
   - avoid heparin products for now
   - no need for argatroban
   .
   # Delirium: Unable to currently assess but has been an ongoing problem
   on the floor.  Likely multifactorial including uremia, hepatic
   encephalopathy and severe infection.
   - Continue CVVH for uremia
   - Continue broad spectrum abx which will cover peritonitis and HAP
   - Follow bcx
   - CIS
   - Try to avoid CNS acting medication; however, currently on fent/versed
   due to increase in abd tenderness and need for patient to remain still
   for CVVH
   .
   # Hematochezia: Resolved.  Has received a total of 3 units prbcs, last
   on [**2-20**].
   - Continue to follow Hct
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T&S
   .
   # C diff. colitis: On PO/PR vanc and IV flagyl given severity of
   colitis. Today ([**3-5**]) is day 14 of antibiotics. Still not producing
   BM
   - Continue PO vanc/flagyl (now has had a 14 day course)
   - cont PR vanco given possibility PO vanco is not getting through
   - Continue to follow stool output, serial abdominal exams
   - would consider IVIG for c.diff if next stool sample still c.diff
   positive
   .
   # Air near tail of pancreas: ? microperf vs pancreatico-colonic
   fistula.  Ascitic fluid amylase of 4.
   - As above, surgery feels patient is poor surgical candidate, will
   readdress based on clinical status
   - Continue to follow exam.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR 2.3, has been elevated throughout admission.
   Likely nutritional and component of liver disease. Patient has received
   multiple doses of vitamin K with little improvement.
   - Continue to follow
   - FFP prior to procedures
   - HCV viral load 509,000 IU/mL
   .
   # DM2: Continue HISS, adjust as needed. insulin in TPN
   .
   # FEN:
   - replete electrolytes

   - Meds via IV
   .

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has hypoxic respiratory failure, which may lead to further deterioration in respiratory function, requiring increased ventilatory support or even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to the presence of C. diff, peritonitis, and possible HAP. This could lead to organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver failure, and cardiovascular instability.
3. Renal failure: The patient has oliguric acute renal failure, which may progress to end-stage renal disease if not managed effectively. CVVH is currently being used, but the patient may require further interventions, such as hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a prolonged INR, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications. This could be exacerbated by the patient's thrombocytopenia and possible HIT.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a high risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, including ileus, obstruction, and perforation, due to the presence of C. diff and possible SBO.
6. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing secondary infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections, due to the presence of multiple lines and tubes.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient has hypotension, which may worsen if not managed effectively. This could lead to cardiovascular collapse, requiring vasopressor support or even cardiac arrest.
8. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient has liver failure, which may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, a condition characterized by altered mental status, seizures, and coma.
9. Pancreatic complications: The patient has a possible pancreatico-colonic fistula, which may lead to pancreatic complications, including pancreatitis, pancreatic abscess, or pancreatic necrosis.
10. Delirium: The patient has a high risk of developing delirium due to the presence of multiple medical conditions, including uremia, hepatic encephalopathy, and severe infection.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.
